node.text:
Glacier National Park is classified as a Class 1 airshed under the Clean Air Act. This designation affords the highest level of air quality protection provided under the Act. 

Fresh air, dramatic views, and pristine water are some of the qualities that draw visitors to Glacier from all over the world. Air quality in the park affects obvious things, like visibility. It also has less obvious impacts - on water quality, forest composition and ecosystem function. 

Glacier has had a permanent air quality monitoring site since 1980. The site includes devices and networks that measure different components of the atmosphere. 

Join us for this Science Friday, as the park's Physical Scientist shows us around the site and explains how we measure air quality in Glacier! 

#ScienceFriday #ScienceInParks #GlacierNationalPark #ParkScience #AirQuality

node.title: Science Friday- What's in the Air?

node.text:
You probably expect that Glacier protects things like bears and rivers. Did you know, though, that the park also protects and preserves over 700 historic structures?

Welcome back to Season Two of Science Fridays with Ranger Melissa! We are so excited to continue exploring, learning, and discovering science and research in the park with you! 
This week, we learn about historic buildings in Glacier from the park's historical architect, Kim Hyatt.

node.title: Science Friday - Historic Buildings of Glacier

node.text:
Have you missed us? Science Friday with Ranger Melissa is back with a great final Science Friday video for you! This week, Melissa goes out with John Waller, the park’s bear biologist, to explore the trail for signs of bears, discover differences between bears in Glacier and elsewhere, and learn about how bears live at different times of year. 

#ParkScience #ScienceFriday #Bears #Hibernation #GlacierNationalPark #WildlifeBiology #ScienceInParks

node.title: Science Friday - Glacier's Bears with John Waller

node.text: This week, we are bringing you a VERY special Science Friday. Ranger Melissa travels to an active archaeological site on the east side of the park to meet with archaeologist Brent Rowley. A river has been eroding away the bank, revealing some incredible things about the history of this place. Watch more to find out what they discover! #sciencefriday #parkscience #archaeology #scienceinparks #glaciernationalpark

node.title: Science Friday - Archaeological discovery with Brent Rowley

node.text:
Do you remember seeing or hearing about the Sprague Fire last year? Most of us recall the fire in terms of our own experience with the smoke, the flames, or the sadness of losing Sperry Chalet. But we don't always consider fire's effects on wildlife habitat. .
This video shows one of our wildlife biologists in the burned area, discussing fire's importance for different bird and mammal species. .
Does Lisa's perspective in the video change your feelings about the Sprague Fire?

node.accessibility_caption: A hand picking a huckleberry from the bush.

node.text:
Have you ever picked huckleberries?

This time of year, you can find ripe Huckleberries (Vaccinium membranaceum) all over the park. Their significance to species like grizzly bears is well known, but these delicious berries have also played a vital (and surprising) role in human history. 

Called nupxamuǂ in Kootenai, apa-oapspi by many Blackfeet, and st̓šá to the Selis-Pend d’Oreille, the sweet berries are a traditional food for indigenous cultures across the west. After being picked in the summer, berries are often laid out in the midday sun or placed next to a fire to dry, preserving nutritious food for year-round consumption. 

By the time congress established Glacier in 1910, the popularity of canning kicked off a new era for huckleberries: a commercial industry. 

Local canneries primarily sold cherries and apples, the two main fruits grown in the area. While huckleberries were less reliable than domestic fruits, they ripened between cherry and apple seasons and were available to pick for free on public land. As a result, canneries began processing huckleberries, which were available in stores as early as the 1920s.

This new market supported families throughout Northwest Montana, who commonly took working vacations to pick the berries during the summer, selling as many as they could. During the Great Depression, many who found themselves out of work got by picking huckleberries.

They were so popular—an estimated 20,000 gallons picked on the Flathead National Forest in 1932—a debate started over whether or not huckleberries would be a more profitable use of forest land than timber! 

Their success led the berries to become increasingly associated with Glacier National Park; Kalispell Wholesale Grocery even sold "Glacier Park Brand" huckleberries. 

A lot has changed since then, but even today, the berries remain as popular as ever. Gift shops and grocery stores sell huckleberry-flavored everything: soda, ice cream, candles, chapstick, liquor, and more.

The best part? You can pick them in Glacier! Just remember the picking limit in Glacier for all edible fruits & berries is one quart per person per day.

Image: A hand picking a huckleberry.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on July 18, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and nature.

node.text:
Have you ever walked along the Continental Divide? The very popular Highline Trail is a long and challenging trek. It can be hiked as an out-and-back, but many visitors choose to make it a one-way journey. Most hikers start at Logan Pass, traverse along the Garden Wall to the Granite Park Chalet, and then hike down to the Loop trailhead below. Since this means starting and ending at different locations, visitors must plan in advance how to arrive and leave from the trailheads.

If you'd like to use the park shuttle system, you must book a “Ticket-to-Ride" reservation for the day using the recreation.gov website. Please note that you can reserve a shuttle ticket for either the St. Mary or the Apgar Visitor Centers, depending on whether you plan to leave from the east or west side of the park. 

These are the only stops where you can validate your ticket. During the assigned time slot listed on your reservation, shuttle staff there can give you a wrist band that will act as a day pass at other stops, allowing you to pick up the shuttle at the Loop at the end of your hike. Be sure to book an early ticket for this hike, as it will take most visitors at least 7 hours to complete. Shuttle tickets go on sale at 8 am mountain time two days prior to the day they are valid.

Due to the popularity of this hike, both the Logan Pass and the Loop trailhead parking lots fill daily before 7 am. If you plan to park at Logan Pass and then catch a shuttle from the Loop trailhead back to your car, this requires arranging for a shuttle wrist band at either the St. Mary or the Apgar Visitor Centers the day prior to your hike, as well as then arriving at Logan Pass very early to find parking.

Happy trails!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on July 17, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Did you know that bears like to hike too?

While some have a running speed over 30 miles per hour, research shows that wild bears typically walk at about the same speed as humans. Additionally, to be most energy-efficient, bears tend to choose routes with a gentle gradient rather than steeper ups and downs.

This means that bears sometimes use trails for the same reason people do—because it’s easier than walking cross-country. While most hikers won’t encounter a bear, it shouldn’t be a complete surprise if you see one using a trail in Glacier. Try to maintain 100 yards of space between your party and any bears, and move off the trail if necessary.

To stay safe in bear country, hike in groups, make noise by calling out or clapping at regular intervals, and be aware of your surroundings. Wind, running water, blind turns, and thick vegetation can make it harder for wildlife to hear, smell, or see that you are approaching. Stay alert for scat, tracks, or other signs of recent activity. It is also recommended that at least one person in each party carries (and knows how to use) bear spray. It’s a relatively inexpensive tool of last resort and has been shown to be the most effective deterrent for startled, defensive, or aggressive animals.

For more information about staying safe in bear country, visit the park's website.

node.accessibility_caption: A close up of a blue bucket held over a fire pit.

node.text:
Effective Saturday, July 17, Stage 1 Fire Restrictions are in effect in Glacier National Park.

To learn about Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, and to stay up to date about fire information in the park, visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/nature/fire-information.htm

node.accessibility_caption: A crowd of people, some on horseback, gather in a parking lot to watch a ceremony with mountains in the distance.

node.text:
Exactly 88 years ago today, a dedication ceremony was held at Logan Pass on July 15 to celebrate the recently completed construction of the Going-to-the-Sun Road, an engineering feat.

The full length of the Road had officially opened to the public four days earlier, on July 11, 1933, allowing automobile tourists to access Glacier’s high country as they traveled through the park.

For the dedication festivities, park cooks prepared a chili lunch for 2,500 people, but ran out of food when over 4,000 actually showed up. Various dignitaries from the US and Canada spoke at the ceremony, including politicians and representatives of the National Park Service, Bureau of Public Roads, Montana State Highway Commission, and the Blackfeet, Salish, and Kootenai tribes. Glacier superintendent E. T. Scoyen read a letter from NPS Director Horace Albright that stated in part, “Let there be no competition of other roads with Going-to-the-Sun Highway. It should stand supreme and alone.”

This photo taken by George A. Grant on July 15, 1933, shows the crowds of people gathering to watch the ceremony. #ThrowbackThursday #tbt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on July 14, 2021. May be an image of Lewisia and nature.

node.text:
What flower would you vote for to be Montana’s state flower?
 
That’s the question that faced Montanans in 1894 when an election was held to decide the state flower.
 
The winner, in a landslide, was bitterroot (pictured). A pink-blossoming perennial, the bitterroot is an excellent symbol for the state. More than just eye candy, the bitterroot is an important spring food source for many of Montana’s indigenous people.
 
Bitterroot is called naqam¢u in Kootenai, eks-ix-ix by some Blackfeet, and sp̓éƛ̓m in Salish-Pend d’Oreille. The botanist Frederick Pursh gave bitterroot its scientific name (Lewisia rediviva) because the specimen that he examined had been collected by Meriwether Lewis, and because of the plant’s ability to grow despite appearing dried up and dead (rediviva means approximately “brought back to life” in Latin). 
 
Finishing behind bitterroot (3,621 votes) in the election was evening primrose (787 votes), then wild rose (668 votes). In 1895, the Montana legislature confirmed the vote and officially made bitterroot a state symbol.
 
Do you think they made the right choice? What flower would you vote for?

Image description: A bright pink bitterroot flower in Glacier National Park.

node.accessibility_caption: Small green plants resprout on a burned hillside among tall burned trees after a fire.

node.text:
Fire season has begun here in the Northern Rockies, and fire is a key part of our forest and grassland ecosystems. It creates a patchwork of habitats that benefit different plant and animal species:

🐦 Many birds, like black-backed and three-toed woodpeckers, thrive in burned areas by eating insects that live on burned trees
🌺 Fire stimulates the growth of grasses and wildflowers, which deer and other ungulates love to feed on
🦅 Raptors and other birds of prey like to hunt in clearings and meadows, but need mature trees to nest and perch in nearby
🌿 Huckleberries, beargrass, aspens, and many other plants are adapted to resprout quickly after a burn

That said, it’s important to make sure we don’t start fires by accident! Campfires are only allowed in designated areas in the park, and please be sure to put them out completely with plenty of water. 

Check with a ranger or campground host when you arrive in the park to see if any additional fire restrictions are in effect (none are currently, but that may change throughout the summer). Thanks for doing your part to prevent human-caused fires!

To learn more about fire in Glacier, check out the Lake McDonald episode of our podcast, Headwaters: go.nps.gov/headwaters

node.accessibility_caption: A column of smoke a sunset, with the words: "Smoke - Column photographed in 2018"

node.text:
Nobody's favorite sign of summer is here: Smoke.

As seen in the first image—taken in 2018—wildland fire smoke often rises in a thick column, resembling a cloud. No matter where a fire started, the wind can blow smoke dozens, hundreds, or even thousands of miles away.

Fire danger is currently "High" here in northwest Montana, and recent lightning storms have sparked small fires in the neighboring Flathead National Forest. 

That said, the smoke currently blanketing much of Glacier did not come from local fires. You can trace most of the smoke seen by our webcams this morning back to wildfires burning in Idaho—blown hundreds of miles to reach us here!

You should expect to encounter smoke on a visit to Glacier this summer, as much of the west is experiencing record-breaking heat and historic drought conditions. Over the weekend, air quality reached "Unhealthy" levels, as measured by the Montana Department of Air Quality. In these conditions, you should limit your outdoor activity to reduce your exposure.

To check on current smoke conditions, visit the Montana Department of Environmental Qualities website. For a visual, check out the park's webcams. To see where smoke is coming from, explore AirNow.gov's Fire and Smoke map. 

You can find links to all of these resources by swiping up in our story today!

Image descriptions: A column of smoke at sunset with text that says "Smoke: column photographed in 2018." 

A smoky view of the mountains above the middle fork of the Flathead River, with text that says "Smoke: conditions on July 12th, 2021.

node.accessibility_caption: A column of smoke a sunset, with the words: "Smoke - Column photographed in 2018"
Smoky mountains seen today, with the words: "Smoke - Conditions on July 12th, 2021"
Photo by Glacier National Park on July 11, 2021. May be an image of nature and sky.

node.text:
Are you an early bird or a night owl? 

We have long summer days here, with sunrise currently around 5:45 AM and sunset around 9:40 PM. Visitors who stay up late on a clear night are rewarded with amazing views of the night sky, as light pollution in the park is minimal, and visibility is high. 

There are many places from which to star gaze in Glacier! Some of the best are locations that overlook wide areas without trees, like lakes and parking lots. When planning your night sky viewing, keep in mind that Going-to-the-Sun Road is very narrow and curvy at higher elevations, and some may be uncomfortable driving such conditions after dark. 

Glacier National Park and our bordering partner in Canada, Waterton Lakes National Park, are together designated as an International Dark Sky Park. This designation comes with some responsibilities, as we must minimize artificial light and protect nocturnal habitat. By reducing light pollution in the two parks, we help animals that rely on darkness to hunt or to hide away from predators. If you’d like to learn more about the preservation of dark skies, check out our website. 

Have you ever noticed the Milky Way on a clear night? Leave your own night sky photos in the comments below!

Image description: Night sky with many visible stars reflected on a lake surface.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on July 10, 2021. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text:
Looking to grab some food? There are many options in and around the park this summer, but food access can be limited in certain areas. Plan ahead! 

In the Lake McDonald area, food services are available at Apgar Village and the Lake McDonald Lodge. In Many Glacier, there are multiple takeout options at the Many Glacier Hotel. Camp stores in a variety of locations have snacks and some prepackaged meals, but there are currently no food services in the Two Medicine and Logan Pass areas. 

Restaurants and stores can be found just outside some park entrances, such as in the towns of St. Mary and West Glacier. When spending all day in the park, please plan accordingly and be sure to carry snacks and plenty of water with you. 

If you bring your own meals, there are designated picnic areas at several scenic locations, such as at Apgar, Fish Creek, Sprague Creek, Avalanche Creek, Sun Point, Rising Sun, Swiftcurrent, Two Medicine, and Bowman Lake. Please be sure to clean up your picnic area fully and pack everything out or use our bear-proof trash bins. This includes all scraps like orange peels and apple cores. Help us keep the wildlife wild! 

What’s your favorite meal to pack for a long day of exploration?

Image description: Picnic tables in a shady, wooded area next to a lake.

node.text:
Have you seen Glacier's new Night Sky Webcam? Located at the St. Mary Visitor Center on the Dusty Star Observatory, this camera showcases Glacier's incredible night sky views. It also captures a video each night, so you don't have to stay up until all hours to watch. In this video at about the 12 second mark, watch for the International Space Station to streak by. #internationaldarkskypark #darksky #halftheparkhappensafterdark #glaciernps

https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/photosmultimedia/webcams.htm

[video description] This silent video shows the night sky at St. Mary gradually passing from dusk to dark and back to daylight again as the stars and Milky Way rotate overhead. At one point a streak of light passes, which is the International Space Station orbiting overhead.

node.accessibility_caption: A man stands next to two log buildings in a clearing surrounded by trees.

node.text:
The Kishenehn Ranger Station, located in the far northwestern corner of the park, is a prime example of an early ranger station in Glacier. The original station was built in 1913 and then rebuilt in 1921 after it burned down. By 1931, the North Fork Road was extended to the station as part of an unrealized plan to complete a loop road around the park boundary.

From the 1910s to early 1930s, ranger stations were built throughout Glacier, particularly along its borders, to manage the new park. The rangers stationed year-round at these remote outposts had a variety of responsibilities. Chief among them was enforcement of the park boundary. Rangers would conduct regular patrols along the trails in their district to reduce poaching and timber theft inside the park.

When they weren’t patrolling, rangers would maintain trails, suppress forest fires, conduct game counts, repair telephone lines, and perform other maintenance tasks. They would record meteorological and wildlife observations in their logbooks, along with accounts of their daily activities.

The buildings at Kishenehn were typical of most early ranger stations in Glacier: main cabin, fire cache, barn, woodshed, and outhouse. Its remote location and limited infrastructure meant the Kishenehn ranger was largely on his own.

When the Going-to-the-Sun Road was completed in the 1930s, the park reduced the number of year-round ranger stations, shifting focus instead to areas that received more visitors. By the end of the decade, Glacier staffed Kishenehn only in the summer, and today the station mostly stands empty except for the occasional ranger patrol or winter use by wildlife researchers. The old road to the station washed out in the 1964 floods and it is now only accessible by primitive trail past the turnoff for Kintla Lake.

Andy Fleutsch, shown here in this photo of the ranger station, was one of Kishenehn’s longest-serving rangers, from September 1931 to October 1934. Ranger stations like Kishenehn are an important part of park history and illustrate how park administration has evolved to meet changes in park use and development over the years.

Photo by George A. Grant, taken August 7, 1932. #tbt
